displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: I would rather do the chemotherapy to get things in check, then if there’s one or two resistant spots to the SBRT you know the very closely blind radiation to that. Patient: Right. Family Member: So is there a specific chemotherapy that you would use or do you have an option for… Doctor: No I think then you can get it xxx]. Patient: xxx]. Doctor: Yeah I wouldn’t do it, I would just call Dr. C___. Family Member: Right, but I’m just… Doctor: Yeah, the standard… Family Member: Are there different types of… Doctor: Yes, there are different… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …types of chemotherapy. The standard one for…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. Patient: Just with… Family Member: With what? Doctor: They’re PKs as you get blood draws every few hours. So you have to sit there though for a good all day long basically. Patient: I have to be like in the clinic or hospital? Doctor: Yeah. But this will have to be… Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws.

Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can’t tell ya. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, unless we stick a needle into the bone and say, “Does cancer come out?” Patient: Right. Doctor: Or is this just a hole there? And, so, part of me has to figure out from what you are saying is - is it better or not better. You know, what’s different? You know, clearly under here, I feel like a quarter. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: Do they die or are they just inhibited? Doctor: Yeah they like ninety nine percent die then maybe not one hundred precent. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So that’s with the injection. Then there’s a little cylinder, a little flexible cylinder about this long – Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: - that can be implanted under the skin. Patient: Um,hum. Doctor: That lasts for a whole year so that you don’t have to get injections. Some people like that because it’s convenient. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have to go back and forth. But typical most common ways is to get an injection every twelve weeks which is like every three months. Patient: Right. Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time?

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Before we started on the Xtandi and everything, you know the study. But since then we really barely even see those lymph nodes and even so they’ve been so small. Family Member: Great. Patient: So does that indicate that what your husband did worked? Family Member: Well no, that’s the bone scan. Doctor: No it doesn’t. Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know.

Family Member: So do you have any experience with the BET inhibitor? Have you seen it work or is it so new that you don’t really know? Doctor: I have experience with a different BET inhibitor. So not this particular one. (Coughs) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -was an injection type of BET inhibitor. This one is a pill. So I think uh, no I really don’t have too much experience with this particular one. The study just opened frankly – Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -- and now we have two or three people who will probably start right around the same time. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think it’s going to come pretty quickly. So the company that our group because our group invented it. It’s a company in France, that is a very experienced company developing new uh radioactive things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That company just got bought by N___ Patient: Oh. Doctor: for five billion dollars. So there’s now a kind of uh a big shift. So I think it’s going to happen. Patient: So it’s going to be? Doctor: But up until now, it’s been this kind of almost called hit or miss, and just because of the way we did things in the U.S., it hasn’t. It’s been very frustrating. And I told you I went to Turkey to some little hospital taking care of this guy. We can give him We invented it. I can’t give it at my hospital. Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: So it’s been used in that way around the world but not, I’m not allowed to. Patient: That’s so tough. I see. Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Have fun. Enjoy the weather. Patient: Let’s see. Six weeks is going to put us in middle of July? Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: End of July.

Patient: No. Doctor: Um hum. Have you been losing or gaining any weight? Patient: Uh, I guess I been Doctor: And do you think that’s because your appetite has dropped or you’re losing even if you’re eating the same amount. Patient: Somewhat the same amount. Doctor: Okay. And can you remind me who lives with you at home? Are you on your own or do you have other family members with you? Patient: Um my sister and my great-niece. Doctor: Sister and great-niece. A-and i-i-is your great-niece working or is she at home? Is she- Patient: She-she work. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhm. She probably gon’ be there Doctor: Okay. Well um, you might be right that the PSA level could be rising. We’ll find out by uh later this afternoon or tomorrow morning at the latest.

Patient: Um, it’s up to you, dear. What’s your take, doctor? I think it, it’s Doctor: It’s been working very well against your cancer… Patient: Okay. And they had my blood tests came back? Doctor: Your PSA’s not back from today, but last time, it was continuing to go down. Patient: What was it? What was it? Doctor: Your PSA was one seventy-three.. Patient: Wow. Wow. Doctor: So, it went from, you know, we started out with Patient: It went from two-fifty. Doctor: It started before that in the, way higher Patient: It went from about a hundred to two-fifty and then about a hundred, to two-fifty, to one-seventy. So, that was just Doctor: Exactly. So, it’s heading in the right direction.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Where it would have been an issue is if you’d gotten so much that you didn’t have any bone marrow reserve left, you know, like you’re perpetually having a low red blood cell count and need a blood transfusion but that’s not you so it’s something we consider but definitely not something we have to fuss about with you. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Just so you know cost wise, you know, no one ponies up money to just do this because, you know, you’re used to having the high ticket items for Zytiga and Xtandi but this is about fifteen thousand a dose so insurance has to clear it because that’s just the drug cost not everything else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, in that sense you might see a bigger invoice, you know, at the end of it but most insurance companies cover it in whole Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did.

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because we have the opportunity. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So here we are. (pause3sec) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Do you want the paperwork to read? Family Member: Yes, please. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh. When would be – when would we get started? Oh, you said you had to get approval through insurance? Doctor: Right. So we’re good. And K___ does the process. And then they almost map out all the days. Now, one thing that I like is you’re young, and your veins look pretty good. Instead of putting a catheter and all that in- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Which is a big to-do, I’m going to send you over there for an assessment. If they think they can just do it right off.

Patient: Yeah. Sleep, sleep is a- Doctor: Listen. Your blood sugar is dismal. Let’s just talk about tired and a blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: Will make you tired. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member: Well, you’ve got one there. Doctor: Huh? Oh, yeah. Family Member: I know I get, I know I get, I’m tired when mine’s high. Sometimes I had a two, and I cut out all sorts of carbs, all carbs basically. Doctor: Three eighty five. People don’t walk around with blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: I told him do the diet I’m doing. Patient: Now when I put it all together I’ve got some of my stuff in there. Family Member: Quit eating all that bread and cereal and stuff. Doctor: Yes. What are you doing? Family Member: Do my diet, honey.
